<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3 is: Controlling expressions shall not be invariant.
Here are exceptions to this rule:
1. Invariants that are used to create infinite loops are permitted.
2. A do-while loop with an essentially Boolean controlling expression that evaluates to false and satisfies the constraints and semantics for an integer constant expression is permitted.
</misra_rule>

<target_code>
Here is the code of metal_linux_irq_set_enable:
```c
static void metal_linux_irq_set_enable(struct metal_irq_controller *irq_cntr,
				       int irq, unsigned int state)
{
	int offset, ret;

	if (irq < irq_cntr->irq_base ||
	    irq >= irq_cntr->irq_base + irq_cntr->irq_num) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR, "%s: invalid irq %d\n",
			  __func__, irq);
		return;
	}
	offset = irq - linux_irq_cntr.irq_base;
	metal_mutex_acquire(&irq_lock);
	if (state == METAL_IRQ_ENABLE)
		metal_bitmap_set_bit(irqs_enabled, offset);
	else
		metal_bitmap_clear_bit(irqs_enabled, offset);
	metal_mutex_release(&irq_lock);
	/* Notify IRQ thread that IRQ state has changed */
	ret = metal_linux_irq_notify();
	if (ret < 0) {
		metal_log(METAL_LOG_ERROR,
			  "%s: failed to notify set %d enable\n",
			  __func__, irq);
	}
}
```

I found no controlling expressions that are evidently invariant and requiring investigation under MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.3. All control statements in the provided function depend on runtime values:

- if (irq < irq_cntr->irq_base || irq >= irq_cntr->irq_base + irq_cntr->irq_num)
  - The expression depends on the parameter irq and on fields of the irq_cntr pointer, which are runtime values; it is not a compile-time invariant.

- if (state == METAL_IRQ_ENABLE)
  - The expression depends on the state parameter passed at runtime; it is not invariant.

- if (ret < 0)
  - ret is assigned from the function call metal_linux_irq_notify(); its value is determined at runtime, so the controlling expression is not invariant.

There are no loops in this function (no while/for/do-while) that would create a potential invariant controlling expression, and none of the above conditionals are constant expressions or compile-time invariants. Therefore no code fragments need to be flagged for investigation under Rule 14.3.
